document.docTitle: The type species of the genus Geotrygon Gosse, 1847 (Aves: Columbidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The type species of the genus Geotrygon Gosse, 1847 (Aves: Columbidae)

paragraph.docTitle:
The type species of the genus
Geotrygon
Gosse, 1847
(Aves: Columbidae )

subSection.paragraph:
Department of Zoology, National Museum, Václavské náměstí 68 , CZ- 115 79 Praha
1
, Czech Republic . E-mail: jiri_mlikovsky@nm.cz
The generic name
Geotrygon
was introduced by
Gosse ( 1847 : 316 )
for some doves from the island of Jamaica and has been subsequently used for the so-called quail-doves of Middle and South America (
Baptista et al . 1997
;
Gibbs et al . 2001
;
Dickinson 2003
;
Dickinson & Remsen 2013
).
Johnson & Weckstein ( 2011 )
and
Banks et al . ( 2013 )
indicated that this genus is polyphyletic. The application of a generic name is determined by its type species (Art. 42.3 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature;
ICZN 1999
; hereafter the Code). A literature search showed that different nominal species have been proposed as the type species of
Geotrygon
, and the situation thus requires clarification.

First,
Reichenbach ( 1853 : xxv)
listed
Columba cristata “Lath.
” [=
Latham 1790
: 596 , who took the name from
Gmelin 1789
: 774 ] as the type species of
Geotrygon
.
Gmelin ( 1789 )
based his
cristata
upon “ Rouloul de Malacca ” of “ Sonner . it . 2 . p. 174 . t. 100 ” [=
Sonnerat 1782
: 174 , pl. 100 ] and “Lesser crowned Pigeon” of “ Lath. syn.
II. 2 .
p. 622 . n. 10 ” [=
Latham 1783
: 622 , where the species was called “Lesser-crowned Pigeon”].
Latham ( 1783 )
based his “Lessercrowned Pigeon” solely upon Sonnerat’s ( 1782 ) “ Rouloul de Malacca ”, and the specimen(s) examined by
Sonnerat ( 1782 )
is/are thus the type of
Columba cristata
Gmelin, 1789
. The description and figure provided by
Sonnerat ( 1782 )
clearly show that
Columba cristata
Gmelin, 1789
is a junior subjective synonym of
Rollulus rouloul (
Scopoli, 1786 : 93
)
, a member of the family Phasianidae (as correctly observed already by
Gray 1844
: 42 ;
Salvadori 1893
: 639 ; and Ogilvie-
Grant 1893
: 225 ).
Peters ( 1937 : 132 )
accepted Reichenbach’s ( 1853 ) designation of
Columba cristata Gmelin
, nec Temminck, as the type of
Geotrygon
, but inexplicably synonymized it with
Columba sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
(for which see below).
Columba cristata Gmelin
cannot be the type of
Geotrygon
, because it was not originally included in this genus (Art. 67.2 of the Code; no exemptions listed by the Code apply here).

Second,
Gray ( 1855 : 100 )
listed
Columba cristata “Temm.
” [=
Temminck 1809
: 20 ] as the type species of
Geotrygon
, and
Salvadori ( 1893 : 564 )
followed him. The taxonomic identity of Temminck’s
cristata
is unclear. The plate 9 accompanying Temminck’s ( 1809 ) text shows a pigeon resembling the Crested Quail-dove
Geotrygon versicolor (
Lafresnaye, 1846 : 321
)
, but with a long tail, and it was said by Temminck (1809 , 1813 : 110 ) to inhabit “iles des Amis” [= Friendly Islands = Tonga Archipelago] in “la mer du Sud” [= Pacific Ocean]. Subsequently,
Temminck ( 1813 : 449 )
treated his
Columba cristata
as identical with
Columba pacifica
Gmelin ( 1789 : 777 )
=
Ducula pacifica (Gmelin)
, a pigeon which differs markedly from
Geotrygon versicolor (Lafresnaye)
. However, van den
Hoek Ostende et al . ( 1997
: 96 ) listed a syntype of
Columba cristata Temminck
in the collections of the Naturalis (Leiden, Netherlands ; RMNH 87738 ), which they identified as
Geotrygon versicolor (Lafresnaye)
. No type specimens of
Columba cristata Temminck
were found in the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France (
Voisin et al. 2004
, 2005 ,
2008
) or in the Lafresnaye Collection in the Museum of Comparative Zoology, Harvard University, Cambridge, USA (
Bangs 1930
;
Peters 1943
). However, Lafresnaye recognized that his
Columbigallina versicolor
is identical with
Columba cristata Temminck
(label data; see
Bangs 1930
: 167 ;
Voisin et al. 2005
: 862 ).
Columba cristata Temminck
cannot be the type of
Geotrygon
, because it was not originally included in this genus.

Third,
Ridgway ( 1916 : 464 )
listed
Geotrygon sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
as the type of
Geotrygon
by monotypy, which is an invalid action, because
Gosse ( 1847 )
originally included in his
Geotrygon
two nominal species. The detailed description provided by
Gosse ( 1847 )
allows the conclusion, as has been already observed by
Salvadori ( 1893 : 573 )
, that
Geotrygon sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
is a junior subjective synonym of
Columbigallina
(=
Geotrygon
)
versicolor
Lafresnaye ( 1846 : 321 )
.

Fourth,
Dickinson & Remsen ( 2013 : 62 )
stated that the type of
Geotrygon
is
Columba cristata
Temminck, 1809
, and that
Reichenbach ( 1853 : xxv)
is the person who designated this species as the type . This further confused the issue, because
Reichenbach ( 1853 )
designated
Columba cristata Gmelin
(not Temminck) as the type of
Geotrygon
. It remains unclear whether
Dickinson & Remsen ( 2013 )
intended to accept
Columba cristata Temminck
as the type of
Geotrygon
(thus incorrectly referring to
Reichenbach 1853
), or whether they correctly referred to
Reichenbach ( 1853 )
and incorrectly attributed
Columba cristata Gmelin
to Temminck.

Fifth,
Banks et al. ( 2013
: 184 ) stated that the type species of
Geotrygon
is
Geotrygon versicolor (Lafresnaye)
, a species originally described as
Columbigallina versicolor
Lafresnaye, 1846
.
Columbigallina versicolor Lafresnaye
cannot be the type of
Geotrygon
, because it was not originally included in this genus.

In summary, four different nominal species were deemed to be the type of the genus
Geotrygon
: ( 1 )
Columba cristata
Gmelin, 1789
; ( 2 )
Columba cristata
Temminck, 1809
; ( 3 )
Geotrygon sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
, and ( 4 )
Columbigallina versicolor
Lafresnaye, 1846
. However, none of these designations is valid for reasons explained above. The Code (
ICZN 1999
) offers a simple solution to this problem.
Gosse ( 1847 )
included two nominal species in
Geotrygon
, including
Columba sylvatica
Gosse ( 1847 : 316 )
and
Columba montana
Linnaeus ( 1758 : 163 )
. Only one of these two nominal species can be the type species of
Geotrygon
(Art. 67.2 of the Code; exemptions listed in Art. 69.2 of the Code do not apply here).

In his main text,
Gosse ( 1847 : 316 )
described his
sylvatica
under the account for “Mountain Witch” as follows: “
Geotrygon sylvatica
. Mihi.” and added, in a footnote, detailed descriptions of both the genus
Geotrygon
and the species
Geotrygon sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
. In this footnote,
Gosse ( 1847 )
linked the English name “Mountain Witch” by asterisk to his introduction and description of the genus
Geotrygon
. On the other hand,
Gosse ( 1847 : 320 )
listed “
Geotrygon montana
” without any associated expression, although he created a new combination for
Columba montana Linnaeus. Thus
, this situation fulfills the provisions of Art. 68.2 . 1 of the Code, which states that “The expressions “gen. n., sp. n. ” [...], or an equivalent, applied before 1931 to only one of two or more new nominal species originally included in a new nominal genus [...], are deemed to be an original designation if no other type species was explicitly designated. ” Due to this,
Geotrygon sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
is the type , by original designation, of the genus
Geotrygon
Gosse, 1847
.

In summary, the type species of the genus
Geotrygon
Gosse, 1847
is, by original designation,
Geotrygon sylvatica
Gosse, 1847
, now considered a synonym of
Geotrygon versicolor (
Lafresnaye, 1846
)
. The generic name
Geotrygon Gosse
is thus available for that group of the quail-doves which will include the species now known as Crested Quaildove
Geotrygon versicolor (Lafresnaye)
.
The preparation of this paper was supported, in part, by the projects DKRVO 2014 / 15 and 2015 / 16 (National Museum 00023272) of the Ministry of Culture of the Czech Republic .
